name: Introduction to Environmental Ideas
long_desc: By recognizing that environmental problems are themselves complex and require insights from both scientific and social perspectives, the Universitywide Minor in Environmental Studies urges students to gain proficiency in different disciplinary habits of thinking about environmental problems. This course fulfills a requirement for the Universitywide Minor in Environmental Studies. This course will introduce students from any undergraduate major at CMU to key methods and approaches for inquiry in the framework of Environmental Studies. Students will build up their ability to recognize and apply diagnostic criteria understand key principles and terms and take part in an informed discussion about ways of seeing, and creating interventions for environmental problems as social and scientific challenges. There are no prerequisites for this course. Students will develop skills and apply concepts to different scenarios of environmental crisis. Preference for course registration goes to students already declared for the Minor in Environmental and Sustainability Studies.

custom_fields.goals: Identify historical and narrative differences in approaches to environment and sustainability, from the late 19th century until present and the implications of these narratives for social justice. Assess differing narratives of causation for problems of environment and sustainability. Contextualize disciplinary perspectives from population ecology historical demography sociology development economics history of science literary criticism anthropology systems analysis with largescale computing as they apply to particular questions of environment and sustainability. Examine ones own perspectives and disciplinary contributions and recognize alternative disciplinary approaches and contributions.
custom_fields.key_topics: Interdisciplinary humanistic, social, and science perspectives for the study of Environment and Sustainability - Concepts about Population from the subdiscipline of Population Ecology, and the history of attempts to apply human-environment models across disciplines (attitudes towards poverty, racism and eugenics, "tragedy of the commons," "population bomb") - Environmental Justice: the application of social justice for environmental problems, typically related to pollution and its impacts
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: None, but this course should not be taken in the first year. It is primarily geared towards sophomore and junior students.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Course requirements - complete all course readings as assigned - participate in class discussion - participate in small group activities during class time - complete short written assignment for each week of class - complete a group project with an individual essay component, to be submitted on Canvas.
custom_fields.relevance: This course fulfills a requirement for the Minor and Addl Major in ESS. Environmental problems are complex and require insights from both scientific and social perspectives. For example, it is not enough to tackle climate change solely by knowing the science; it is also very important to communicate well, and to understand the relevant ethics, economics, policy, and business aspects. In addition to the example of climate change, this course includes and draws awareness to concepts coming from different disciplines, especially humanistic disciplines, calling these "Environmental Ideas." The course builds competence for students to identify, and name, different approaches for dealing with complex problems of environment and sustainability.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Mostly ebooks available through CMU Libraries and pdfs linked on Canvas. The course relies heavily on Canvas web-based resources.
